channel.title: Outside.In on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti
channel.description: Recent content in Outside.In on Vacuum weblog from Edward Vielmetti

item.title: outside.in "top local blog" roundup: what exactly am i writing about here?
item.description:
outside.in is a blog aggregator; it scoops up posts from around the net, codes them by geography, and then presents you the reader with a feed that's local to whatever you want it to be local about.  Here is the outside.in Ann Arbor page .  I get their newsletter sent to me which ends up being a good day's local news clippings.

Here's their roundup of top Ann Arbor blogs and bloggers; Vacuum is listed as a top local blog. They describe what I write about as follows:

Vacuum - A love of the neighborhood library and awareness of local school news, political happenings, tech updates and the occasional recipe make this eclectic blog a must read.

It's always interesting to figure out what other people thing you are doing - if you are trying to maintain a laser-like coherent focus on being eclectic, it's hard to know what to do next.   I'm happy that recipes make for good filler.

To give credit where credit is due, here's perhaps better sources for any of the components that go into this effort:

Libraries: my main library blog is Superpatron which spun out of Vacuum about two years ago.  Locally the Ann Arbor District Library site has a bunch of blogs inside it including a good one on local history, Globally my short list for library inspiration includes Jenny Levine's The Shifted Librarian, Michael Stephens writing Tame The Web, and self-described library geek John Blyberg's eponymous blog.

Local school news: the Burns Park Elementary PTO has a web site and newsletter  which I clip from regularly (mostly, it seems, to remind myself of things in the future).  The Ann Arbor Chronicle has good coverage of school meetings which I am never ever likely to attend regularly.  The very busy arborparents mailing list connects parents across town and across the area - more news than I can readily absorb but always something of interest and a very helpful bunch for asking questions of.

Political happenings:  I think the outside.in people were keyed on to my elections coverage; rather than take any kind of political stance visibly here at all in any tedious partisan way, I try to always collect as much details as I can on elections including sample ballots and polling place locations and times.   The best sources for that are county clerk Larry Kestenbaum's occasional blogging, plus a certain degree of digging through municipal web sites.  The City of Ann Arbor's email alert service helps a lot.

Tech updates: This leaves broad room for interpretation.   In the useful but sometimes tedious realm, techmeme is the only tech news tracker you need to listen to the silicon valley echo chamber.  Collecting more local tech news is helped by Issue Media Group's Concentrate and by Matt Roush's Great Lakes IT Report, both of which are eager to write about local stuff.  My a2b3 weekly lunch group and the mailing list that goes with it are my local collection source for interesting people and projects and tech (and note that quite a bit of this is pre-market projects not yet in the Silicon Valley radar).

The occasional recipe: The relentlessly practical answer to how this gets done is "blog what you eat"; if you are persistent about that, you get ready-made menu plans for next year around the same time.   Locally, I turn to Kate Remen-Wait's Four Obsessions blog when I need a menu idea,  Kitchenchick for reviews of local restaurants, and The Farmer's Marketer for a market list from the Ann Arbor Farmers Market.  Globally the technique is "google cooking" or "twitter cooking" where you simply type in a list of ingredients into either search box and hope someone has something inspiring.

Eclectica.  It's imporant to be fed a steady diet of things which are interesting; if creativity is an import-export game, then this is the import side of that.  Reliably I pull from my network on delicious for great weird ideas.  There are a few weblogs that specialize in the eclectic, most notably Lindsay Marshall's Bifurcated Rivets: A Compendium of Eclectica for Epopts.

so there you go.
